I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia requested knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to support the implementation of the National Program 
on  Gender  Equality  (2017–2021)  and the  Ulaanbaatar  Declaration,1 adopted  under TA for 
Gender-Responsive Sector and Local Development Policies and Actions financed by the Japan 
Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR).2 The TA is consistent with the objectives of ADB’s country 
partnership strategy, 2017–2020 for Mongolia.3 In line with ADB’s Strategy 2030, ADB will support 
Mongolia’s efforts to achieve gender equality by supporting enforcement of gender equality 
legislation and strengthening collaboration with civil society organizations (CSOs).4 The TA is 
included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2019–2021 for Mongolia.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Gender inequality is an obstacle to economic growth and poverty reduction, and the 
Sustainable  Development  Goals  prioritize  gender  equality  and  women’s  empowerment. 6 
Mongolia is committed to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals, and the TA will support 
Mongolia by strengthening policies and legislation aimed at promoting gender equality and 
women’s empowerment. 
 
3.  Mongolia has a comprehensive gender legislative framework, but enforcement remains 
inadequate because of (i) limited capacity and accountability of government institutions to conduct 
gender analysis and mainstream gender in policy planning and budgeting; (ii) insufficient cross-
sector coordination by the government, including with CSOs; (iii) a lack of sex-disaggregated data 
in some sectors; and (iv) the prevalence of strong gender stereotypes in all spheres of society, 
as revealed by the study on public perceptions and attitudes on gender inequality issues under 
previous JFPR-funded TA (footnote 2). For instance, out of 1,000 respondents, over 70% of men 
think men should hold executive position in government while women should take implementing 
positions.  Further,  women  of  various  ages  with  differing  levels  of  education  highlighted 
pronounced gender-specific barriers that hinder their access to jobs and career opportunities. As 
a result, a relatively large share of women (40.5%) are employed in precarious informal work and 
unpaid family work (women spend more than twice as much time on caregiving duties and 
household chores as men). Women participate far less in entrepreneurial work than do men, and 
the imbalance is most acute in rural areas. In 2016, 33.6% of all workers (35.4% of all men and 
31.7% of all women) were employed in agriculture, but women are not reaping the full benefits of 
their labor in the pastoral economy. Across all immovable assets, women account for less than 
40% of dwelling owners and around 20% of agricultural land owners.7

4.  Effective engagement of civil society at all levels is crucial to ensure local government and 
service  providers  are  accountable  to  the  public.  An  estimated  19,260  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs) are registered in Mongolia, with about 21% operating at the local level. 
However,  local  NGOs  lack  experience  in  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E)  and  public 
communication  to  promote  gender  equality  at  the  grassroots  level.  Although  the  Law  on 
Promotion of Gender Equality, adopted with ADB’s support in 2011, stipulates the importance of 
civil society’s role in monitoring the implementation of the law, the government does not prioritize 
capacity building of CSOs. Effort is also needed to reach out to the private sector, particularly 
micro  entrepreneurs,  to  support  women’s  entrepreneurship  and  gender  inclusive  practices 
through financial and nonfinancial support, including training on financial literacy and facilitation 
of access to markets for businesses owned by women. 
 
5.  ADB has actively engaged with the National Committee on Gender Equality (NCGE) in 
Mongolia since 2009, including by supporting the design and adoption of the gender equality law, 
and through capacity building for effective law enforcement. As shown by international good 
practice, implementing the gender equality legislation based on sector-specific gender strategies 
is critical. In this regard, the government has accelerated policy initiatives through the adoption of 
the National Program on Gender Equality, and sectoral and local-level gender policies and 
subprograms since 2016. The TA will build on previous ADB support to ensure the practical 
application of the policy documents on gender equality at national, sector, and local levels, while 
fostering the sustainability of the policies.8 The TA will also complement ongoing regional TA for 
deepening civil society engagement for development effectiveness.9 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) gender equality in political, legal, economic, 
social,  cultural,  and  family  relations  substantially  promoted;  and  (ii)  sustainable  social 
development objectives ensuring gender equality substantially achieved.10 The TA will have the 
following outcome: CSOs’ engagement in implementation of gender equality programs at national, 
sector, and local levels improved.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output  1:  Knowledge and  understanding  of  government  staff,  nongovernment 
organizations, and private sector to operationalize gender agenda improved. To ensure the 
practical application of the national, focus sector, and local gender equality programs, the project 
will provide training (i) on gender mainstreaming for about 151 local government officials working 
in public administration, food, agriculture, and light industries of Selenge aimag (province);12 and 
(ii) on participatory M&E of focus sector gender policy implementation for about 20 NGOs working

in the food, agriculture, and light industry sectors. To support women’s entrepreneurship and 
disseminate  gender-inclusive  workplace  guidelines  for  private  sector,  developed  under  the 
previous JFPR-funded TA (footnote 2), the project will provide training on financial literacy, 
business development skills, and green jobs for about 59 informal micro, small, and medium-
sized enterprises owned by women of Selenge aimag that operate in focus industries. To promote 
professional networking among civil society, the TA will (i) establish and furnish a resource hub 
in the existing NCGE Secretariat facility; and (ii) organize a speaker series among CSOs, media, 
and development partners. 
 
8.  Output 2: Implementation of subnational gender equality programs monitored and 
evaluated by local nongovernment organizations. Building on training provided under output 
1 and to increase the engagement of CSOs in the implementation of subnational gender programs, 
the project will train about 100 selected local NGOs of 21 aimags (4–5 NGOs per aimag) on:13 (i) 
participatory  M&E  of  local  gender  equality  subprogram  implementation  and  (ii)  public 
communication skills to facilitate community sensitization on gender equality through regional 
training. A toolkit for participatory M&E of local gender subprogram implementation will be 
developed for NGOs. The training programs on public communication skills will build on insights 
and knowledge products from the 2016 JFPR TA (footnote 2) tailored to specific community 
stakeholders. The project will select 15 local gender and/or women’s NGOs from five aimags to 
pilot participatory M&E on local gender equality subprogram implementation; the M&E results will 
inform the NGOs’ recommendations to local governments. Women will be the predominant TA 
beneficiaries, as Mongolian NGOs typically comprise a much higher percentage of women than 
men. 
 
9.  Output 3: Gender-related knowledge products disseminated and public awareness 
raised. This output will produce focused knowledge products on a range of key gender issues. 
Based on a gender analysis of young herders’ livelihoods, a workshop will be held to provide 
policy recommendations on addressing gender issues among herders. A high-level national forum 
will be organized to reinforce implementation of the Ulaanbaatar Declaration (footnote 1) adopted 
under the 2016 JFPR TA (footnote 2). Further, to facilitate gender studies on climate change 
adaptation and improvement of rural women’s livelihoods, up to five research proposals of 
researchers and scholars will be funded, with findings presented to the national symposium. To 
sensitize the public regarding gender stereotypes, innovative messages (e.g., using story-telling 
video clips and/or podcasts, and social marketing techniques) will be produced and disseminated 
nationwide in collaboration with high-capacity NGOs, building on the gains of the JFPR TA 
(footnote 2). The TA will engage the 15 trainee NGOs (para. 8) to help them identify, design, and 
implement  local  communication  campaigns  targeted  at  their  communities,  and  will  thereby 
increase community-driven outreach on gender equality, and ensure NGOs are able to apply 
lessons and insights regarding public communication skills. 
 
10.  The TA will extend ADB’s engagement with CSOs nationwide through focused training 
programs and innovative, pro-poor, socially inclusive, and gender-responsive “learning-by-doing” 
approaches. Specifically, the 15 trainee NGOs will (i) pilot participatory M&E on the gender 
equality subprogram implementation in their aimags and (ii) design and implement communication 
campaigns for their respective communities where the impact can be most significant. The 
participatory M&E toolkit developed under the TA can be replicated to other sectors and the 
remaining 16 aimags. The TA also addresses gaps and adds value to capacity building of local 
women entrepreneurs. 
                                                
13 Selection criteria will include (i) expertise on social, gender, human rights, and development issues; (ii) at least 2 
years of continuous practical experience; and (iii) prior experience working with local government.

4 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $530,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the JFPR and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The 
government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff remuneration, office 
accommodation for project implementation unit staff, meeting venues, operation and maintenance 
costs of the resource hub, logistics and administrative support of workshops and training, and 
other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will implement the TA from 1 August 2019 to 1 August 2021. The NCGE Secretariat 
will be the executing and implementing agency. The NCGE Secretariat will form and chair a 
steering committee to guide the TA, composed of senior officials from relevant ministries and 
agencies. The TA  coordinator  will  act  as  a  secretary  to  the  steering  committee.  ADB  will 
administer the TA and be responsible for the recruitment and contracting of all consultants in 
coordination with the executing agency (EA). 
 
13.  To facilitate TA implementation, ADB will establish a separate advance payment facility 
with the NCGE Secretariat in a commercial bank in local currency (togrog) in coordination with 
the Ministry of Finance following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). This will be used to support cash expenditures for workshops, 
training programs, conferences, and publications; local travel costs of the EA staff; and other 
miscellaneous administration and support costs with prior agreement from ADB. The TA will 
support local travel costs of the EA staff for the facilitation of extensive trainings in rural areas, 
including per diems and vehicle rentals. The TA will not support ineligible expenditures following 
the JFPR policy guidelines. The EA is assessed as having the financial management capacity 
and internal control to maintain records.14 ADB will also make certain direct payments (e.g., for 
procurement of equipment and furniture, workshop venues).

15.  Consulting services. ADB will hire two individual consultants (a TA coordinator and a 
finance and administrative assistant) to provide support across all three outputs. ADB will also 
engage two national consulting firms: one will focus on gender and M&E, and the other will deliver 
public communication activities.15 Output-based terms of reference will be used to recruit the 
public communications firm using the quality-based selection method. Interested organizations 
will be requested to prepare a full technical proposal, including a methodology and approach to 
deliver the outputs and determine the number of experts required to achieve the set objectives. 
ADB will engage consultants in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
ADB will evaluate TA progress through semiannual review missions based on the performance 
targets and indicators defined in the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 2. 
 
16.  ADB’s  procurement.  ADB  will  procure  equipment  and  furniture  following  the  ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. This may include office equipment, computers, 
tablets, projector, LED screen, furniture, and automated facilities. The equipment and furniture 
procured through the TA will be turned over to the NCGE Secretariat upon TA completion. 
 
17.  Cofinancier requirements. The TA will liaise closely  with local CSOs  whose local 
presence and specialized knowledge will help in addressing gender inequalities that constrain 
poverty reduction and inclusive growth. The TA is designed with strong grassroots participatory 
approaches, given its target of civil society activists working to help the poor, vulnerable and other 
marginalized groups, and youth not commonly involved in decision making that affects their lives. 
The TA will be implemented following the 2018 JFPR Policy Guidelines for TA grants. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to the Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Moving Gender Equality Forward through Civil Society Engagement, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
